Idiom (Somali): Mar i dage allah ha dago, laba i dage anaa is dagnaye
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Complex conditional clause, uses past tense verb with emphatic reflexive
Figurative Meaning: Fool me once, shame on you; fool me twice, shame on me
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: One should learn from past mistakes
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Pan-Somali wisdom, popularized through oral storytelling
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Somali): /maɾ ʔi dɑɡɛ ʔɑlːɑ hɑ dɑɡo, lɑbɑ ʔi dɑɡɛ ʔɑnɑː ʔis dɑɡnɑjɛ/
First Example Sentence: Haddii qof kuu been sheego mar hore waad iska cafin kartaa, laakiin mar labaad haddii uu kuu been sheego, mar i dage allah ha dago, laba i dage anaa is dagnaye.
Second Example Sentence: Waalidka hadalkaas ayuu adeegsadaa marka ay carruurtoodu ku celceliyaan qaladaadkooda.
Third Example Sentence: Macallinku wuxuu idiin sheegayaa, mar i dage allah ha dago, laba i dage anaa is dagnaye, markuu idiin digayo in aad casharka dhagaysataan.

Idiom (Somali): Soo helay sac, se wuxuu cunaa hilib bisil
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Simple clause, third-person verb usage with relative clause
Figurative Meaning: He found an opportunity, but seeks only comfort or already finished success
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: Someone avoids effort and only wants rewards
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Somali): /soː hɛlɑj sɑʕ sɛ wʊhʊ ʕunɑː hɪlɪb bɪsil/
First Example Sentence: Cabdi soo helay sac, se wuxuu cunaa hilib bisil, markasta wax dhammaysan ayuu doonayaa.
Second Example Sentence: Markaan howsha bilaabnay ayuu yimi asagoo filaya in wax walba la dhammeeyay.
Third Example Sentence: Maamulaha wuu ka cadhooday, wuxuuna yiri, 'Soo helay sac, se wuxuu cunaa hilib bisil.'

Idiom (Somali): Hilibkuba hadduu bislaado, lafihiisana way jilcaan
Figurative Meaning: When things go well, even hardships become manageable
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Pastoral wisdom from Somali nomadic life
First Example Sentence: Wuxuu yiri, hilibkuba hadduu bislaado, lafihiisana way jilcaan, marka nasiibku wuu la socdaa dadaalka.
Second Example Sentence: Shaqada badan ayaa keenta in xalal laga helo caqabadaha.
Third Example Sentence: Hooyaday waxay ku oran jirtay, hilibkuba hadduu bislaado, lafihiisana way jilcaan.

Idiom (Somali): Dab shiday doqon baa dabayl ku shiday
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Relative clause, past tense, passive structure
Figurative Meaning: A foolish person worsens an already bad situation
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Proverbial wisdom from clan conflicts and community dynamics
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Somali): /dɑb ʃidɑj dɔqɔn bɑː dɑbɑjl ku ʃidɑj/
First Example Sentence: Xaaladdu way adkayd, dab shiday doqon baa dabayl ku shiday.
Second Example Sentence: Madaxweyne hadalkaas wuxuu la mid yahay dab shiday doqon baa dabayl ku shiday.
Third Example Sentence: Wuxuu qabtay go'aan xun, taasoo ahayd mid hor leh—dab shiday doqon baa dabayl ku shiday.

Figurative Meaning: If you benefited from something, don’t criticize it
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: Don't bite the hand that feeds you
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Moralistic saying common in Somali hospitality norms
First Example Sentence: Af wax cunay xishoo, haddii aad wax ka faa’iiday, ka aamuso ceebtooda.
Second Example Sentence: Ma ogtahay in aad adigu hore ugu naalootay? Af wax cunay xishoo!
Third Example Sentence: Waa hadal hooyaday ku tiraahdo markaad ceebeyso qof ku caawiyay.

Figurative Meaning: One person alone can't handle everything
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Common across Somali households to promote cooperation
First Example Sentence: Shaqo badan ayaa jirta, far keliya fool ma dhaqdo.
Second Example Sentence: Macallinku wuu yiri, ardaydu waa inay wada shaqeeyaan, far keliya fool ma dhaqdo.
Third Example Sentence: Waa hubaal, guusha kooxdu waa muhim—far keliya fool ma dhaqdo.

Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: Only hard work leads to reward
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Traditional Somali work ethic expressed proverbially
First Example Sentence: Haddii aad rabto guul, nin aan dhididin ma dhaxlo.
Second Example Sentence: Kaalinta hore ma ahan mid lagu helo raaxo, nin aan dhididin ma dhaxlo.
Third Example Sentence: Waa hadal ku dhiirrigeliya shaqaalaha—nin aan dhididin ma dhaxlo.

Idiom (Somali): Meel xun meel kale looma tago
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: Don't flee trouble by jumping into more trouble
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Traditional conflict-avoidance advice in Somali elders' circles
First Example Sentence: Xaaladaas wuu ka cararay, balse meel xun meel kale looma tago.
Second Example Sentence: Hooyo waxay igu tiri, 'Meel xun meel kale looma tago.'
Third Example Sentence: Markaad go’aan khaldan qaadato, waa inaad xasuusataa, meel xun meel kale looma tago.

Figurative Meaning: What's lost is not yours anymore
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: Let go of what you’ve lost
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Pastoral teachings on resilience and detachment
First Example Sentence: Waa inaad aqbasho xaqiiqada, wixii kaa lumay lama leeyahey.
Second Example Sentence: Markuu telefoonkii iga lumay, hooyaday waxay tiri, wixii kaa lumay lama leeyahey.
Third Example Sentence: Waxa luntay wuu iloobay, wixii kaa lumay lama leeyahey.

Idiom (Somali): Nin waliba saad u dhaqanto ayuu kuu dhaqmaa
Figurative Meaning: People treat you the way you treat them
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Somali): /nɪn wɑlɪbɑ sɑːd ʔu ðɑqɑntɔ ʔɑjʊː kuː ðɑqmɑː/
First Example Sentence: Nin waliba saad u dhaqanto ayuu kuu dhaqmaa, sidaad dadka ula dhaqanto waa muhiim.
Second Example Sentence: Islaanta waxay tiri, ‘Nin waliba saad u dhaqanto ayuu kuu dhaqmaa.’
Third Example Sentence: Dugsi walba wuxuu leeyahay sharaf—nin waliba saad u dhaqanto ayuu kuu dhaqmaa.
